title: 106_s1001
content: The Act is titled the "National Youth Violence Commission Act" and establishes the National Youth Violence Commission. The National Youth Violence Commission is established with 16 members appointed based on expertise in relevant matters. The National Youth Violence Commission is established with 16 members appointed based on expertise in respective fields. Members are appointed for the life of the Commission by the President of the United States, the Speaker of the House of Representatives, and other officials. The National Youth Violence Commission is established with 16 members appointed based on expertise in various fields, including law enforcement, school administration, teaching, counseling, parenting, family studies, and child or adolescent psychology. Two members are appointed by the Minority Leader of the House of Representatives. The National Youth Violence Commission has 16 members appointed based on expertise in law enforcement, school administration, teaching, counseling, social sciences, and religious leadership. Members are appointed by the Majority Leader of the Senate and the Minority Leader of the House of Representatives. The National Youth Violence Commission consists of 16 members appointed by the Majority Leader of the Senate and the Minority Leader of the House of Representatives. The Commission includes members with expertise in law enforcement, school administration, teaching, counseling, social sciences, and religious leadership. The appointments must be completed within 30 days of the Act's enactment, and any vacancies will not affect the Commission's powers. The Commission's vacancies will not affect its powers and must be filled within 30 days. The appointing authorities will jointly designate a Chairman within 45 days of the Act's enactment. The Commission shall meet within 30 days of the appointment of the last member or when funds are available. A majority of members constitutes a quorum for business, with the option to establish a lesser quorum for hearings. Each member has one vote. The Commission members each have one vote of equal weight. They can establish additional rules for conducting business by majority vote, as long as they align with the Act and other laws. The Commission members have equal voting rights and can establish additional rules by majority vote, as long as they comply with the Act and other laws. The Commission is tasked with conducting a study on youth violence to determine its root causes, including factors like teacher and parent involvement in students' lives. The study on youth violence includes examining relationships, involvement, and awareness of parents and teachers, as well as the alienation of youth from schools and peer groups. It also looks at the availability of firearms to youth, the impact of media violence, and the accessibility of information on weapon construction. The Commission will gather testimony from parents and students to understand the root causes of youth violence. Based on the study findings, recommendations will be made to address these causes and reduce incidents of youth violence. The Commission will also consider any reports issued by the Surgeon General on media and violence when making recommendations. A report must be submitted within 1 year of the study completion. The Commission will submit a comprehensive report to the President and Congress within 1 year of its first meeting, including findings, conclusions, and recommendations. The report will also include summaries of reports from contracted research entities and other materials used in the report preparation. The Commission has powers outlined in Section 4. The Commission may hold hearings, administer oaths, take testimony, and receive evidence to carry out its duties. Witnesses appearing before the Commission shall be paid fees. If a person fails to provide requested information, the Commission may request the Attorney General to issue a subpoena for the necessary documents. The Commission may request the Attorney General to issue a subpoena for necessary documents, including computer files or data, to carry out its duties. The subpoena may require the production of materials from any place within the United States. Additionally, the Commission may request the Attorney General to issue a subpoena for interrogatories to understand materials obtained through a previous subpoena. The Attorney General may issue a subpoena for materials in response to interrogatories from the Commission, with a complete recording of any deposition. Individuals must certify the authenticity of submitted materials, with false statements subject to penalties under federal law. Any false statements regarding the certification required under this paragraph are subject to penalties under federal law. Subpoenas issued by the Attorney General must comply with the requirements of subpoenas issued by a United States district court. Failure to obey a subpoena may result in the Attorney General applying to a United States district court for compliance, with disobedience punishable as civil contempt. The Commission may obtain information from Federal agencies to fulfill its duties. Information obtained must be kept confidential to comply with federal law. The Commission can obtain confidential information from Federal agencies as required by law. This information can only be disclosed to Commission employees, upon court order, or when publicly released in a non-identifying manner. The Commission can contract for research with any entity to fulfill its duties under section 3, while ensuring that any confidential information obtained from Federal agencies is protected under section 1905 of title 18, United States Code. Commission personnel matters are addressed in Section 5. Members of the Commission, not federal government officers or employees, receive compensation equal to level IV of the Executive Schedule. Government officers or employees serve without additional compensation. Commission members are allowed travel expenses as per rates authorized for agency employees under title 5, United States Code. The Chairman of the Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director and necessary personnel without following civil service laws. The executive director's compensation should not exceed the rate for level V of the Executive Schedule. Other personnel's compensation can be determined by the Chairman without following chapter 51 provisions. The Chairman of the Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director and necessary personnel without following civil service laws. Other personnel can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement, and temporary services can be procured at rates determined by the Chairman. The Chairman of the Commission can appoint an executive director and personnel without following civil service laws. Temporary services can be procured at rates not exceeding the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay for level V of the Executive Schedule. Authorization of appropriations is granted to the Commission and relevant federal agencies to carry out the Act's purposes. The funds appropriated have no fiscal year limitation and will remain available until expended. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting the required report.
